editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msDesc.head: GILES OF ROME; S. XIV in.

msItem.note: Fols. i, iiv blank. On f. iv is an early table of contents and notes; on f. ii more early philosophical notes.

msItem.author: GILES OF ROME
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Generatione et Corruptione
msItem.incipit: Anima ut testatur philosophus est quodammodo omnia
msItem.explicit: generationis omnis est principium causa et ratio qui ...

msItem.author: GILES OF ROME
msItem.title: Quaestiones in I De Generatione
msItem.incipit: Vniversaliter itaque de generatione &c. Hic ad euidentiam textus declaranda sunt quattuor
msItem.explicit: non est illi generatio sed augmentum.

msItem.author: GILES OF ROME
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, Physica
msItem.incipit: Naturalis scientia est aliqua scientiarum speculatiuarum
msItem.explicit: consistit summa felicitas qui est Deus trinus et unus benedictus in s. s. amen.
msItem.finalRubric: Sit nomen Domini benedictum quoniam completa sentencia libri phisicorum est edita a fratre Egidio Romano ordinis heremitarum S. Augustini. Deo gratias.
msItem.note: On f. 204v is a pen trial, s. xv; 205rv blank.
Arts 1 and 3 are corrected in the margin by the scribe and in early anglicana hands which also annotate. In the margin of art. 1 is ‘Hic incip’’, suggesting that the text was used for lectures.

supportDesc.extent:
207 leaves (ii + 205) 305 235
245 165
The edges retrimmed affecting marginalia and spattered with red.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with crayon in 2 cols of c. 56 lines.

handDesc.handNote: An English gothic rotunda bookhand of university type.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue flourished initials with long extensions; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; art. 1 has running heads in capitals of the colours. Art. 2 is undecorated.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on seven bands; formerly chained from near the head and near the foot of the back board. f. i, formerly pasted down in an earlier binding, has the mark of both a brass and iron chain-staple near the foot.

history.provenance: Given to the College by William Reed in 1374: UO49. 13. On f. iv, in Reed’s hand,‘Liber M. Willelmi Red ex dono magistri Nicholai de Sandwyco. Oretis igitur pro utroque’, and, in the hand of Walter Robert, ‘Liber domus scolarium de Merton’ in Oxon’ in communi libraria eiusdem et ad usum communem sociorum ibidem studencium cathenandus. Ex dono uenerabilis patris domini Willelmi tercii episcopi Cicestrie. Oretis igitur pro eodem et benefactoribus eiusdem ac fidelium animabus a purgatorio liberandis.’ For William Reed, fellow from 1344 until at least 1357, d. 1385, see MS 8.

At the head of f. ii is a brief, highly-abbreviated note, of which I can only decipher ‘B. et an cheste
tot’.
At the head of f. 1 is the James no. ‘101’, s. xvii in.
Inside the front board is a sheet of paper with contents, s. xvii, and ‘Q. 3. 7. Art:’, canc. and replaced with ‘N. 1. 4 (CCCV)’ in red; the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.
